holdings.text: those provisions of section 35 (3) are directory and not mandatory and that any omissions in the manner of service of the notice are mere irregularities which would not vitiate the proceedings unless it was shown that those irregularities had prejudicially affected the proceedings

anchor.surface_text: The following provisions (omitting the words not material to this case) would show that those provisions of section 35 3  are directory and number mandatory and that any omissions in the manner of service of the numberice are mere irregularities which would number vitiate the proceedings unless it was shown that those irregularities bad prejudicially affected the proceedings- No resolution of a municipality deemed invalid on account of any irregularity in the service of numberice upon any companyncillor or member provided that the proceedings of the municipality were number prejudicially affected by such irregularity.

anchor.surface_text: As there are no such saving clauses in express or implied terms, it must be held that the amendment was clearly intended by the legislature to apply to all cases of election of president or vice- president, whether or not the matter had been taken to court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear language deems elections valid retrospectively from 11 May 1954; applies to pending proceedings per precedents (Singer, Mukerjee); no saving clause

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bombay Act LIV of 1954 retrospectively validates elections for residue term <1 year; deems in force from 11 May 1954

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines procedural validity and retrospective validation

precedents.citation: The King v. The General Commissioners of Income-tax for Southampton Ex parte W. M. Singer 1 [1916] 2 K.B. 249, 259

anchor.surface_text: There is clear authority to the contrary in-the following dictum of Lord Reading, C.J. in the case of The King v. The General Commissioners of Income- tax for Southampton Ex parte W. M. Singer 1 ,- I cannot accept the contention of the applicant that an enactment can only take away vested rights of action for which legal proceedings have been commenced if there are in the enactment express words to that effect. There is noauthority for this proposition, and I do not see why in principle it should be the law. But it is necessary that clear language should be used to make the retrospective effect applicable to proceedings commenced before the passing of the statute. That was a case in which the Act in question had 1 1916 2 K.B. 249, 259

precedents.case_name: The King v General Commissioners of Income Tax for Southampton ex parte W M Singer
precedents.cited_proposition: An enactment can retrospectively affect pending legal proceedings without express words stating so, provided the language clearly makes the retrospective effect applicable to such proceedings
precedents.cited_holding: I cannot accept the contention of the applicant that an enactment can only take away vested rights of action for which legal proceedings have been commenced if there are in the enactment express words to that effect. There is no authority for this proposition, and I do not see why in principle it should be the law. But it is necessary that clear language should be used to make the retrospective effect applicable to proceedings commenced before the passing of the statute.

precedents.citation: Mukerjee, Official Receiver v. Ramratan Kuer 1 [1935] L.R. 63 I.A. 47

anchor.surface_text: A number of authorities were cited before us but it is only necessary to refer to the decision of their Lordships of the Judicial Committee in Mukerjee, Official Receiver v. Ramratan Kuer 1 , which is clearly in point. In that case while an appeal had been pending before the Judicial Committee the amending Act had been passed clearly showing that the Act was retrospective in the sense that it applied to all cases of a particular description, without reference to pending litigation. In those circumstances their Lordships pointed out that if any saving were to be implied in favour of pending proceedings, then the provisions of the statute would largely be rendered nugatory. Those observations apply with full force to the present case, inasmuch as if any saving were to be implied in favour of cases pending on the date of the amendment, the words all elections [...] 1 1935 L.R. 63 I.A. 47.

precedents.case_name: Mukerjee Official Receiver v Ramratan Kuer
precedents.cited_proposition: A retrospective amending Act that applies to all cases of a particular description applies also to pending litigation of that description, without need for express saving of pending proceedings, otherwise the statute's provisions would be rendered nugatory
precedents.cited_holding: if any saving were to be implied in favour of pending proceedings, then the provisions of the statute would largely be rendered nugatory
